title: Heating and thermal transformation of micrometeoroids entering the earth's atmosphere
abstract: The present numerical solutions for the atmospheric entry of 10 micron-1 mm diameter micrometeoroids gave attention to ablative mass loss and cooling, together with gravitational and curvature effects, for entry velocities in the 11.2-72 km/sec range. Maximum temperature and mass-loss rates are found to generally occur at altitudes between 85 and 90 km, during about 1 sec of peak heating; the survival of all particles in the 70 micron-1 mm size range is noted to be limited to those with minimal entry velocity. Virtually all of the 'cosmic spherules' of more than 70-mm diameter, as well as giant unmelted micrometeorites, are implied by the present results to be of asteroidal origin.
